awd_titl_txt: Phase III IUCRC Ohio State University: Center for Smart Vehicle Concepts (SVC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Industry University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Smart Vehicle Concepts (SVC) has earned national visibility and a position of technical leadership in the area of smart materials applied to automobiles and air vehicles. The mission of SVC will focus on: conduct basic and applied research on smart materials in pre-competitive mode for application to vehicles; develop an unmatched base of research, engineering education, and technology transfer considering emerging needs in the industry; and develop engineers and researchers who not only understand theory but have experimental and system integration expertise.  The Center thus creates the science necessary to transition smart materials from the concept stages to vehicle applications, while advancing broader national needs toward promoting diversity in engineering education; advancing U.S.-based expertise, resources, and human capital; and creating and disseminating knowledge at all levels including undergraduate and doctoral students, post-graduate researchers, and practicing engineers.

The work done in Phase II allowed SVC to formulate critical research questions and identify technical challenges that hinder the implementation of smart materials in vehicle design.  Counting with the enthusiastic support of the Industrial Advisory Board, the Center has formulated a five-pronged strategy for addressing these challenges: (i) expand the SVC faculty base, especially focusing on junior faculty; (ii) attract additional vehicle integrators and suppliers of components and materials; (iii) adapt the Center?s research portfolio on smart materials to evolving needs in the industry; (iv) continue efforts to collaborate with other institutions and attempt to attract additional academic partners. The sponsors have provided ample evidence of how the Center has made contributions of commercial significance to their organizations. During Phase III, the Center will implement a new research roadmap that builds on its existing strengths while also creating a new thrust dedicated to emerging vehicle technologies, namely vehicle electrification, autonomous vehicles, and structural lightweighting. Within the new research matrix, SVC plans to generate scholarly research of common interest, foster cross-pollination across the automotive and aerospace sectors, engage in technology transfer activities, and promote industry-focused student training as a means to build the future employee base of the transportation sector.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Ohio State University (OSU) has successfully completed its Phase III NSF grant supporting the IUCRC on Smart Vehicle Concepts (SVC). Since its founding as a Phase I Center in 2007, SVC has earned national and international visibility and a position of leadership in the area of smart materials applied to automobiles, aircraft, rotorcraft, and space vehicles.

During the graduated (Phase IV) phase, the mission of SVC continues be as follows: (1) conduct basic and applied research in pre-competitive mode toward developing new vehicle systems, sub-systems, and components; (2) build an unmatched base of research, engineering education, and technology transfer with emphasis on improved vehicle performance, structural lightweighting, electrification, and smart mobility; and (3) develop well-trained engineering professionals and researchers who possess both theoretical understanding and experimental expertise.

Intellectual merit - During Phase III, the Center has established a technical and operational framework featuring a new sustainability plan that allows it to adapt SVC's faculty team, research portfolio, and national presence to the evolving needs of the transportation industry. The framework included a seed grant program meant to attract faculty into the Center toward building a robust base of research leaders, students, and collaborators focused on supporting existing sponsors and attracting new corporate partners and Center memberships. In consultation with the Industrial Advisory Board, the Center deployed a revised research matrix aimed at investigating how advanced materials can enable solutions and innovations in emerging technological areas. Four research thrusts were developed: (a) interfacial mechanisms; (b) safety, comfort, and health monitoring; (c) adaptive noise, vibration, and harshness; and (d) emerging vehicle technologies (vehicle electrification, autonomous vehicles, lightweighting). Lastly, the Center negotiated a new membership agreement that underpins its self-governance as a graduated IUCRC while preserving the same operational structure and membership levels utilized during the NSF award period. Such approach was implemented in collaboration with the IAB and OSU's research leadership, and it has been met with enthusiasm by all of SVC's stakeholders.

Full members during the NSF award period include: Advanced Numerical Solutions, American Axle and Manufacturing, Army Research Laboratory, Autoliv, Battelle Memorial Institute, Bridgestone Americas Tire Operations, Daimler Truck North America, Eaton Innovation Center, Edison Welding Institute, F.tech R&D, Ford Motor Company, Goodyear Tire & Rubber, Honda D&M Americas, Hyundai-Kia Motors, MIT Lincoln Laboratory, Moog Inc., NASA Glenn Research Center, Owens Corning, Parker Hannifin, REL Inc., Solidica, Tenneco, The Boeing Corporation, Tokai Rubber, Toyota Research Institute, and Transportation Research Center.  Affiliate and observer members during the same period include BorgWarner, LMS/Siemens Software, MSC Software, MES Inc., Romax, and YUSA.

Further details on SVC's membership structure, research, and operations can be found at https://svc.osu.edu/.

Broader impact - SVC has maintained throughout the three NSF phases an emphasis on scholarly research of common interest, fostering cross-pollination across the automotive and aerospace sectors, and promoting industry-focused student training as a means to build the workforce of the future. Nearly 20% of Center students gained employment with SVC sponsors upon graduation. Contributions made by the SVC team of researchers and students have made it possible for smart materials and functional structures to make inroads in vehicle design, enabling the translation of smart materials from the laboratory to commercial products while training the next generation of engineers as savvy smart material users. The Center has established an excellent track record of creating translational research that combines PhD-level scholarly research with classroom and continuing education. The Center has successfully involved researchers from underrepresented groups and has spawned research experiences for undergraduate students (NSF REU), graduate students (NSF INTERN), faculty exchanges at members' facilities, and a range of sponsored projects from government agencies that provided leverage to SVC projects.

Center activities involved 64 projects, yielding 377 journal publications and 174 conference proceedings publications for a combined total of over 550 publications throughout the three phases.  Over 400 students have been supported by SVC throughout the three phases with 225 PhD, 92 masters, and 90 undergraduate students supported. Nearly 150 SVC students have graduated since 2007 including 51 PhDs, 61 masters, and 35 undergraduate students. The number of invention disclosures, patent applications, and patents granted have continually increased as a result of project maturation with 80 inventions disclosed; 47 US and international patent applications submitted with 16 patents having been issued to SVC researchers.


Last Modified: 08/23/2023
Modified by: Marcelo Dapino
